profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Salem, Conn., May 9, 1772; was graduated from Yale College in 1791; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Le Roy, Genesee County, N.Y., in 1793; moved to New York City in 1794 and continued the practice of law; elected as a Federalist to the Thirteenth Congress (March 4, 1813-March 3, 1815); member of the State assembly in 1820 and 1821; moved to Albany in 1821; served in the State senate in 1822; reporter of the New York Court of Chancery 1823-1826; member of the commission to superintend the construction of Sing Sing Prison 1825-1830; judge of the State circuit court 1832-1836; died in Geneva, Ontario County, N.Y., March 9, 1837; interment in Washington Street Cemetery.

note.content: One of two elected to represent 21st district.

researchRecord.name: In the Eliphalet Nott Papers, 1822, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Eliphalet Nott to Samuel M. Hopkins written on February 21, 1822. In the letter, Eliphalet Nott solicits influence for the extension of a loan to Union College in anticipation of a grant from the state lottery.

researchRecord.name: In the David Daggett Papers, 1809, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from David Daggett to Samuel Miles Hopkins concerning the apprenticeship of his son in a law office.

researchRecord.name: In the Samuel Jones Papers, 1826, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Samuel Jones to Samuel M. Hopkins written on February 28, 1826. The letter concerns a recommendation.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Benjamin Tallmadge Papers, 1809 and 1820, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: Two letters from Benjamin Tallmadge to Samuel M. Hopkins. The letter written on September 28, 1809 concerns the estate of Oliver Phelps, and the letter written on July 19, 1820 concerns a place for Benjamin Tallmadge's son who wishes to become a farmer.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Peter B. Porter Papers, 1822, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A copy of a letter from Peter B. Porter to Samuel M. Hopkins written on September 12, 1822. In the letter, Peter Porter proposes that a harbor be constructed at either Buffalo or Black Rock.

recordLocation.name: Buffalo and Erie County Historical Society

researchRecord.name: In the Mathew Carey Papers, 1825, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Mathew Carey to Samuel M. Hopkins in thanks for the prison report and requests another copy. Mathew Carey also inquires about obtaining the public documents of Samuel Hopkins's legislature.

researchRecord.name: In the John Trumbull Papers, 1800, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Trumbull to Samuel M. Hopkins written on September 5, 1800. In the letter, John Trumbull is sending some law books and comments on which works are deemed most authoritative in various branches of the law.

researchRecord.name: In the Egbert Benson Papers, 1786-1819, 10 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Samuel M. Hopkins. An unpublished guide is available in the repository.
